Read a FBM from a file

Florian Privé

July 2, 2018

read-FBM-from-file.Rmd

In this vignette, you will learn how to read a Filebacked Big Matrix from a text file. We will see how to use function big_read through examples.

First example

Store a fake file

N <- 10 
M <- 5
(x <- matrix(rnorm(N * M), nrow = N, dimnames = list(letters[1:N], LETTERS[1:M])))
##            A           B          C          D          E
## a -0.5012842 -1.01638112  0.6431569  0.3010146  0.1773628
## b  1.0769175  0.87507547 -1.0000411 -1.6684975 -0.3992185
## c -0.9635243 -1.81573157  1.5019412  0.7688201  1.0585572
## d  1.2057561  1.84850172  0.8021510 -0.1745887  0.5372155
## e  0.9124845 -0.06139848  3.0403706  0.7956344  0.7706572
## f  0.4069333 -1.95886051 -0.6632168  0.6026123  1.5658110
## g  1.7947611 -1.85962067  0.9394588  1.4280654  0.7438458
## h  0.2049261 -0.26905033  1.0338126  1.3316962  0.1952131
## i  0.2558195  0.61503663 -0.4861771 -1.7211329  0.4495153
## j  0.9697344  0.08757377 -0.3309853 -0.2722960 -0.2550894
csv <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv")
data.table::fwrite(cbind.data.frame(L = letters[1:N], x), csv, quote = FALSE, sep = " ")

Get some intuition on the file format

I think it is always a good idea to print the first lines of the file you are interested in reading.

substr(readLines(csv, 3), 0, 60)
## [1] "L A B C D E"                                                 
## [2] "a -0.501284242982575 -1.0163811233929 0.643156853779931 0.30"
## [3] "b 1.07691749512552 0.875075471697452 -1.00004111033554 -1.66"

What you can see with these first 3 lines:

  • the first line of the file stores some names (header),
  • the first element of all following lines stores also some names,
  • the elements are separated by a space,
  • the elements are doubles.

Read the file

# See how the options corresponds to what we have seen 
# when reading the first 3 lines of the file
test <- big_read(csv, header = TRUE, sep = " ", confirmed = TRUE)
## Will use blocks of 10 lines
## Will add 1 more columns to meta information.
## Will create a 10 x 5 FBM of type 'double'.
## Will create a 10 x 1 df of meta information.
str(test)
## List of 3
##  $ FBM     :Reference class 'FBM' [package "bigstatsr"] with 6 fields
##   ..$ extptr     :<externalptr> 
##   ..$ nrow       : int 10
##   ..$ ncol       : int 5
##   ..$ type       : Named int 8
##   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "double"
##   ..$ backingfile: chr "/tmp/RtmpqtaKtO/file4914587a845.bk"
##   ..$ address    :<externalptr> 
##   ..and 17 methods, of which 3 are  possibly relevant:
##   ..  initialize, save, show#envRefClass
##  $ colnames: chr [1:5] "A" "B" "C" "D" ...
##  $ meta    :'data.frame':    10 obs. of  1 variable:
##   ..$ L: chr [1:10] "a" "b" "c" "d" ...

Understand the resulting object

There are at least 2 things to note:

  1. where are the names?

    • rownames are stored in $meta information

    • colnames are stored in $colnames

    (rownames <- test$meta$L)
    ##  [1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" "f" "g" "h" "i" "j"
    (colnames <- test$colnames)
    ## [1] "A" "B" "C" "D" "E"

  2. the resulting matrix is stored in $FBM. If you want this FBM to be used in another session later, make sure to specify the backingfile and save = TRUE.

    str(test$FBM)
    ## Reference class 'FBM' [package "bigstatsr"] with 6 fields
##  $ extptr     :<externalptr> 
##  $ nrow       : int 10
##  $ ncol       : int 5
##  $ type       : Named int 8
##   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "double"
##  $ backingfile: chr "/tmp/RtmpqtaKtO/file4914587a845.bk"
##  $ address    :<externalptr> 
##  and 17 methods, of which 3 are  possibly relevant:
##    initialize, save, show#envRefClass

Second example

A larger dataset

big_iris <- do.call("rbind", rep(list(iris), 1000))
dim(big_iris)
## [1] 150000      5
csv <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv")
data.table::fwrite(big_iris, csv, quote = FALSE)

Get some intuition on the file format

readLines(csv, 5)
## [1] "Sepal.Length,Sepal.Width,Petal.Length,Petal.Width,Species"
## [2] "5.1,3.5,1.4,0.2,setosa"                                   
## [3] "4.9,3,1.4,0.2,setosa"                                     
## [4] "4.7,3.2,1.3,0.2,setosa"                                   
## [5] "4.6,3.1,1.5,0.2,setosa"

What you can see with these first 2 lines:

  • there is a header,
  • the first 4 columns seems numeric but not the last one,
  • the elements are separated by commas.

Read the matrix

str(test <- big_read(csv, header = TRUE, sep = ",", confirmed = TRUE))
## Will use blocks of 150000 lines
## Will add 1 more columns to meta information.
## Will create a 150000 x 4 FBM of type 'double'.
## Will create a 150000 x 1 df of meta information.
## List of 3
##  $ FBM     :Reference class 'FBM' [package "bigstatsr"] with 6 fields
##   ..$ extptr     :<externalptr> 
##   ..$ nrow       : int 150000
##   ..$ ncol       : int 4
##   ..$ type       : Named int 8
##   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "double"
##   ..$ backingfile: chr "/tmp/RtmpqtaKtO/file491472c9c05e.bk"
##   ..$ address    :<externalptr> 
##   ..and 17 methods, of which 3 are  possibly relevant:
##   ..  initialize, save, show#envRefClass
##  $ colnames: chr [1:4] "Sepal.Length" "Sepal.Width" "Petal.Length" "Petal.Width"
##  $ meta    :'data.frame':    150000 obs. of  1 variable:
##   ..$ Species: chr [1:150000] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" ...
